The Cupids had left all the Lawns,</br>The Shepherds fell out about Pan;</br>The Noise had affrighted the Fawns,</br>And all the kind Wood-doves were gone.
The Reeds had forgot their sweet Strains,</br>Nor murmur'd so soft as before;</br>Disputes had distracted the Swains,</br>And Love was regarded no more.
Poor Damon might talk to the Wind</br>His Passion for Nisa the Fair;</br>And think, and think on, till he pin'd;</br>And sigh till he vanish'd to Air.
The Shepherds sad Comforters prove;</br>Talk nought but of Pan, and the Times;</br>Inhumanly banter his Love,</br>And call it all Whining, and Rhimes.
To shun all their Jeers, and their Strife,</br>He flies to a neighbouring Cave,</br>To lament the hard Fate of his Life,</br>And hopes 'twill be shortly his Grave.
Against the damp Rock he reclin'd,</br>Like a languishing Lover, his Head:</br>"My Soul now unload thy whole Mind;</br>Here none can upbraid thee," he said.
He thought it a kind of Relief,</br>Whilst here he lamented alone;</br>Kind Echoes repeated his Grief,</br>In Plaints full as soft as his own.
"O!  all ye soft Powers above,</br>And must I be silent and die?</br>Did Nisa but know how I love,</br>The Charmer cou'd never deny.
"Young Colin had skill to complain,</br>And mingle such Art with his Woe;</br>The Nymphs were all touch'd with his Pain,</br>And Tears from the Nereids flow.
"But Damon, a plain-hearted Swain,</br>On mere simple Truth must rely:</br>But what can mere Truth hope to gain</br>In a Lover, so artless as I?
"What Oceans of Love through me roll!</br>Oh!  'tis not in Words to impart</br>The Billows, that hang on my Soul;</br>The Sorrow, that choaks up my Heart.
"Why, ye Fates, was I destin'd to bear</br>A Sorrow, I cannot reveal?</br>Or kill me, or help me declare</br>To Nisa the Passion I feel."
Young Colin stood listening near,</br>And thus he surprizes the Youth;</br>"If Nisa is human, she'll hear:</br>Ah!  Damon, no Language like Truth.
"Go tell her your own artless way;</br>Great Passions can ne'er be express'd:</br>Simplicity still wins the Day;</br>She knows how to guess at the rest.
"True love in a Soul, that's sincere,</br>Is better than Language, or Art:</br>Fine Similes tickle the Ear,</br>But Nature will soften the Heart."
"'Tis done — I have writ to my Fair;</br>But tremble to wait the Reply:</br>Ah!  Nisa, true Lovers are rare;</br>May Damon be happy, or die."</br>
